MainHeading.P: Chuaigh an Ceann Comhairle i gceannas ar 2.30 p.m.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Civil Service Career Breaks.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach the number of civil servants in his Department who are currently on career breaks; the grades of the officers con cerned and the length of time for which the break was granted in each case; if any persons, while on career breaks, have been retained by his Department on a consultancy basis or any other basis involving financial remuneration; and if so, the numbers involved and the level of remuneration in each case.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. Barrett, Dún Laoghaire) Nuala Fennell
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. Barrett,
Speaker.P: Dún Laoghaire): There are four staff of my Department currently on career breaks as follows: 1 assistant principal for a period of two years from 1 October 1984; 1 higher executive officer for a period of one year from 24 September 1984; 1 clerical assistant (typist) for a period of three years from 25 June 1984 and 1 clerical assistant for a period of one year from 19 October 1984.

MainHeading.P: None of these officers has been retained by my Department on a consultancy basis or any other basis involving financial remuneration.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: Would the Minister indicate what purpose these career breaks serve and what value he believes they are to the Civil Service?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): That information was not requested by the Deputy. I should say that the persons who got these career breaks complied with the criteria laid down by the Department of the Public Service.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: The Minister indicated that none of the staff referred to has been re-employed by the Department of the Taoiseach. Could he indicate whether any of them has been employed by any other Government Department or by any of the Dáil committees?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): That is a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Might I ask the Minister of State if there is any, even remote, possibility that the Taoiseach himself would take a career break?

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: The Deputy himself has had one for a few years.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: The Deputy has had his career break. If the Taoiseach does, it will be taken in the circumstances in which the Deputy took his.

Speaker.hpid: The Tánaiste Dick Spring
Speaker.P: I am glad to see that the internal pressure is off Deputy Haughey.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: Seeing that the Minister of State is not prepared to answer any supplementaries, would he indicate whether he would consider it to be an abuse of the system of career breaks for civil servants to take such a career break and then be re-employed by the Civil Service in another capacity at a higher level of remuneration?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The question does not cover that. The Deputy appears to be availing of the question to discuss the policy of career breaks which does not arise from the question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): I have answered the question as tabled by the Deputy. None of the officers concerned has been retained within the Department — which was the question he asked — on a consultancy or any other basis involving financial remuneration.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: I want a fairly simple answer — because it must be Government policy — would the Minister of State consider it to be an abuse of the system if a person was re-employed, while on a career break by another Government Department or by any of the Dáil committees?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am calling Question No. 2.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Fitzgerald Mr. L. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he will intervene with An Bord Iascaigh Mhara to ensure that no confiscation will take place in the cases of trawler owners who are trying earnestly to repay their loans; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole) Paddy O'Toole
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole)
Speaker.P: It is not the policy of Bord Iascaigh Mhara to repossess fishing vessels except in cases where the board are satisfied that for one reason or another the skipper is unable and unlikely to meet his loan commitments. I do not propose to intervene in the matter which falls within the day-to-day operations of the board.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Could the Minister give us an indication of what is the current arrears situation in relation to boat repayments and whether An Bord Iascaigh Mhara have any proposals at present to repossess any boats?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Twelve vessels were voluntarily surrendered in 1983 and eight vessels in 1984. This action was taken by the board having established that not only were these people not in a position to meet their commitments but, in many cases, did not even have insurance cover on such commitments. In reply to the Deputy's question, I should say proposals are at present being examined in relation to this problem and I hope to be in a position to make an announcement on this fairly shortly.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Last week the Minister was not in a position to give us any information in relation to the proposals at present before either his Department or the Department of Finance. Perhaps the Minister could avail of this opportunity to give us some details of the nature of the proposals, whatever they are, in order to deal with this crisis in relation to loan repayments.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I cannot give details of the proposals because they have been put by the board to me. I have had discussions with the board and I am now having discussions with the Department of Finance. Until these matters have been finalised it would be inappropriate for me to give details of what the proposals are.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Can the Minister give the exact amount of money owed? Is it in the region of £6 million or £8 million and is it true that the proposals are delayed in the Department of Finance because the Department are not prepared to sanction them?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: The Deputy is indulging in wild speculation in relation to the figures he mentioned and the location of the proposals.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Begley Mr. Begley
Speaker.P: Will the Minister give an assurance that boats which are repossessed will be sold to citizens of the State?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: That is a matter for the board of BIM. I do not normally intervene in their day-to-day activities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Would the Minister accept that the number of boats repossessed is the highest ever? Would he not accept that this is a clear indication of the serious position of the fishing industry? Would he ensure that the practice is not allowed to continue whereby boats are left lying and fall into disrepair? They should be in good repair when they return to fishing.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I am not in a position to say whether this is the highest level of repossessions because we are not comparing like with like. The level of repossession in previous years may possibly have been lower but the number of boats in the fleet was lower. It is difficult to make direct comparisons. I agree that the laying up of boats over a long period is a bad practice since it leads to the deterioration of the boats.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Would the Minister ascertain the number of the boats lying up and try to ensure that they are not left in a condition which would make it impossible for them to return to fishing? New boats have been left lying up for two years.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I promise the Deputy that I will take up this matter with the board of BIM.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: The Minister did not give precise details of the size of boats and the areas in which they were repossessed. Could he give some indication of the areas in which these boats were operating and the exact amount owed?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: This matter should not be raised. The question deals with the future.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I have not that information for the obvious reason that this is a matter completely outside the parameters of the question.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Fish Processing Industry.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Flaherty Miss Flaherty
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he will explain the total underdevelopment of the fish processing industry in Ireland; and whether there are any plans for State initiative to stimulate the development of fish processing.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole) Paddy O'Toole
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole)
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is aware, the establishment of fish processing plants is primarily a matter for private enterprise in the first instance. In order to promote such development assistance is afforded by State agencies such as An Bord Iascaigh Mhara, the Industrial Development Authority and Údarás na Gaeltachta, as appropriate, for suitable projects. Such projects can also attract grant aid under the EEC marketing and processing scheme.
I do not accept the implication in the question that the Irish fish processing industry is totally underdeveloped.

Capital investment in the fish processing sector has in the five years 1979-1984 (October) amounted to £26.7 million, of which State grants constituted £7.0 million and EEC (FEOGA) grants £5.9 million.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: The Minister will be aware that in relation to secondary processing there is a huge potential for job creation and benefit to the economy if a more vigorous policy is adopted. Can the Minister indicate whether his Department or BIM have any arrangements or have had discussions with the IDA to ensure that more attention is given to secondary processing of our own produce with a view to creating additional employment opportunities and added value for the State?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: BIM encourage processing, particularly secondary processing. To this end BIM work closely with the IDA, Údarás na Gaeltachta, the ICC and AnCO. BIM place special emphasis on product and process development, refrigeration, plant lay-out and quality control. They at all times encourage processing.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that a number of promoters have sought to establish fish processing industries at Rossaveal, the only major fishing harbour on the west coast, and that they have not been able to proceed due to delays in the further development of Rossaveal harbour? This has been held up for the past three years.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: It has been held up for somewhat longer than three years. It is a specific question and if the Deputy puts it down I will give full details.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: The question relates to fish processing.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Question No. 3 as drafted is a very general question and the Deputy is now raising a specific matter on which the Minister could not be expected to have information in his brief.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: The question seeks information on a State initiative to stimulate the development of fish processing. I am asking whether the Minister is aware that there are promoters who are very anxious to establish fish processing plants at Rossaveal. Plans for the development of the harbour have been in the Minister's Department for perhaps five years. We cannot understand why no decisions have been made on these development plans. Whatever delays were occasioned when Fianna Fáil were in office, two years have passed and the project should have been put out to tender and started. Why is the Minister holding it up now?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I am not holding it up.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: The Minister will be aware that the lack of processing capacity is hampering the development of certain species. Is he aware of the possibilities in a number of areas which are not being exploited and has he any plans to initiate in BIM a new drive to open up processing of species which have not been utilised up to now? What does he proposes to do about it?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: There is an on-going interest in new areas of processing. The IDA, Údarás na Gaeltachta, the ICC and AnCO are involved with BIM in searching out and following up inquiries from private individuals.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Question No. 4.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: What are the prospects like for the next three or four years?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Very good.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: How many are employed in processing?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I have not the numbers.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Land Acquisition Post Vacancy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry the reasons that the position of acquisition inspector for County Galway in his Department has not been filled to date despite the fact that this position is vacant for the past four months; if he is aware that the public are not getting the type of service that they are entitled to on account of this situation; the date on which he proposes to fill this vacancy; and if he will make a statement on the entire situation regarding land acquisition.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: In the present situation the filling of each vacancy must be considered in the context of the implication for the Department of the embargo governing the curtailment of numbers in the public service. This inevitably entails deployment of available staff in such a way as to achieve the optimum benefit for the Department.
The vacancy in question was filled on 22 October 1984.

MainHeading.P: It is expected that, in all, some 5,000 hectares, 12,500 acres, of plantable land will be acquired by my Department in the current year, as against 4,000 hectares last year. I am confident that the intake level will increase further during the period of the national plan.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: What is the reason for the second biggest county, one that has to cope with a big disadvantage in that it has a lot of fragmented land, being without an acquisition inspector for a long period? Is the Minister aware that proposals submitted to his Department were dealt with by remote control from Dublin? Is the Minister aware that services for small farmers in those disadvantaged areas were not available during that time and that decisions were made that were not to the satisfaction of local farmers?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: A long statement like that is not in order at Question Time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: The vacancy that arose there has now been filled. As the Deputy realises because of the system we operate throughout the public service one does not fill vacancies overnight. A certain process must be gone through for a Department to get a suitable person to fill a vacancy. That has been gone through in this case. The vacancy has now been filled.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: Is the Minister stating that the person who filled the vacancy came from outside the forestry division?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I am not implying any such thing.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: How can the Minister justify the delay when there were senior experienced staff available to be promoted?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Consequential vacancies arise from such a movement within a Department and arrangements must be made to fill such vacancies as a consequence of moving one official.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: I should like to point out to the Minister that farmers in the southern part of the country have experienced great difficulties.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: We cannot have speeches at Question Time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: I am not making a speech but I am anxious to mention the dissatisfaction in the area.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy was in the course of making a speech.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: I was drawing attention to the dissatisfaction in the area based on my question.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy will have to avail of a debate on an Estimate for that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: It is a serious matter when proposals from small farmers in the southern part of County Galway to the Department for an exchange of arable land held by the Department for commonages they own have not been accepted. It is a serious matter that the Department have put mechanically propelled vehicles on this land.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That does not have anything to do with the question. It is not a supplementary question. The Deputy need not assume a pained or aggrieved appearance.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: Will the Minister meet a deputation representing those farmers and terminate the excavation work being carried out by these mechanically propelled vehicles until he has done so?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will find out if he asks me, I am at all times available to meet any deputation that he suggests on any issue relating to my Department. I await with interest the Deputy's deputations.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: Will the Minister stop the work by the mechanically propelled vehicles?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I will talk to these people in a civil fashion.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McEllistrim Mr. McEllistrim
Speaker.P: Will the Minister outline the reasons for the non-appointment of an acquisition officer or is it true to say it was because his Department did not have any funds to purchase land for afforestation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: That is not so.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McEllistrim Mr. McEllistrim
Speaker.P: There is no money in County Kerry and I am sure the position is the same elsewhere.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is aware, there is always money in Kerry.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Disposal of Forest Timber.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he will make a statement on the review of the procedures for the disposal of timber by his Department which was carried out recently.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I presume the Deputy is referring to the interdepartmental committee who have been examining the tender-quota systems for disposal of State-owned timber.
The committee's report has been presented to the Government and I hope to be in a position to issue a public pronouncement in the matter shortly. When I say “shortly” I mean in a matter of days.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Will the Minister indicate what the general policy will be in this regard?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I should like to point out that it is not normal practice when a report has been presented to me to release details of it without first publishing it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Was there an internal difference of opinion in the Department as to the way policy should proceed?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I should like to say that there is no minority report in the final document presented to me.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Did the Minister silence them?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Brennan Mr. P. Brennan
Speaker.P: The interdepartmental committee have been very slow, almost 12 months behind time, in reporting to the Minister. On more than one occasion the Minister said he was expecting the report shortly. Today the Minister has told us he expects to make a statement in a few days now that the Government have considered that report and I should like to know if we can expect it to be published in a few days.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: The Deputy may.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: What will be the value of the report in view of the fact that another committee have been established by the Minister? What will the relationship be between the committees? Will this report be sent to the other committee for further consideration and then sent to the Government?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: That depends on how the review committee view the contents of the report to be published in the next few days.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: It is a review about a review.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leonard Mr. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry the amount allocated to each county for forestry in 1984 under the programme for western development.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: The overall provision for the forestry element of the western package in the current year, namely £110,000, is not pre-allocated on a county basis. Expenditure by county depends on the level of planting undertaken in each county.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: The figure of £110,000 brings the total for three years to less than £250,000 out of an allocation from Brussels of £1.8 million. Will the Minister agree that that represents a hopeless performance by the Department?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That seems to be argument.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I do not accept that it represents a hopeless performance by my Department. I should like to tell the Deputy that the scheme to which he referred, a very generous one carrying an 85 per cent grant level in relation to the small western package, has been very disappointing in that only 10 per cent of the money available has been taken up so far. If the Deputy wishes I can give him the relevant figures. I should like to tell the Deputy that 75 per cent of the area approved for planting in that period was not planted and that was not the fault of the Department. In that I include my predecessor.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: In 1981, the first year, £61,000 was taken up, £74,000 in the second year and £110,000 this year and one would have thought that such an expenditure over those three years would have helped to get the scheme off the ground. Is it not time to examine the fact that it did not get off the ground especially when the grant aid for it is so generous? I understand that it is the highest grant aided scheme in any Department, Agriculture or Forestry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I accept that the take-up level of the scheme has been most disappointing. To add to the grant aid there is also free professional advice available. There are probably many reasons for the lack lustre performance of the scheme, historical and so on, but it was disappointing and I would like if Deputies tried to promulgate the message that the scheme carries a very generous grant level in relation to land which is not being used to its full potential. The scheme is eminently suitable for land use in these areas.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: Bearing in mind that the scheme has not been successful is it not time to bring the heads of Departments together and decide whether to abolish it or make a job of it?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: The Deputy appears to be blaming the heads of sections in my Department or me. The fact is that people are aware of the scheme. We have put in advertisements, provided personnel for lectures on the scheme where invited; we have published brochures, booklets and so on, and have been in touch with ACOT. You can bring a horse to water but you cannot make him drink and that, unfortunately, is the position in this case, but hopefully it will improve in the future.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McEllistrim Mr. McEllistrim
Speaker.P: I would like to ask about the advertising of this scheme. In my view the Department neglected to advertise this scheme because if it had been properly advertised, more farmers would be inclined to avail of it. Many farmers do not know about the grants available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: We have advertised the scheme in journals, newspapers and so on, and also through statements made by me and my Minister of State, but I accept that we will have to undertake a more intensive advertising campaign to see what the uptake will be.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: In view of the disappointing response to the scheme, has the Minister any proposals to review it? Is he aware that probably part of the reason for the poor uptake were the very poor prospects and return for investment in forestry? The Minister will be aware that recent statements by the Minister of State have added to the confusion because many farmers are under the impression that a new improved scheme is about to be launched.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: New proposals are being considered at the moment. The Deputy asks if we are reviewing the scheme. In normal circumstances a review of a scheme would imply an improvement of a scheme, but we are talking here about a current level of 85 per cent. I do not think anybody could possible expect us to provide grant aid at a higher level. In relation to the implication in the Deputy's question that the reason for the poor take up might be the fact that farmers must wait a long time for a return on their investment, I do not accept that, because at present many people are interested in purchasing established forests — six, seven or eight year old forests. This is not a long time to wait for a return on an investment when one considers that an 85 per cent grant for forestry development is being made available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: It is desirable that small farmers and people in a position to avail of this scheme be encouraged to invest in this area, but even with the best will in the world the Minister must accept that there is a time lag between investment and first returns. If this situation could be improved, it would encourage farmers to get into this scheme. Has the Minister any plans to help farmers in the early years?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I have no plans. Because of the generosity of the current plan, I do not consider there is a need for it.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Question No. 7.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: May I——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: We have debated this question long enough.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: I would like a final clarification from the Minister on the statement by the Minister of State about the new scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: That is a different question. The question I was asked relates to the existing scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: This is having a very serious impact on farmers. Will the Minister give some details of what he has in mind?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Is the Deputy trying to say that the Minister of State has one plan and I have another?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: The Minister of State——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: That is an erroneous statement. We are at one in relation to these plans.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Forestry and Timber Industry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he will establish a new State-sponsored authority — An tÚdarás Adhmaid — as proposed by the Irish Timber Council in their policy statement issued on 3 July 1984; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if his Department has yet completed its examination of the recommendation of the National Planning Board that a semi-State body be established to run the forestry and timber industry; the results of the examination and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he will make a statement on the terms of reference etc. of the Review Group on Forestry announced by him on 7 November 1984.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he has any plans to replace his Department with a semi-State body as was done with the Department of Posts and Telgraphs.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 7, 8, 9 and 10 together.

I have no plans to replace the Department of Fisheries and Forestry with a semi-State body on the lines suggested. Neither are proposals for the establishment of a timber authority or board being considered by me.

MainHeading.P: The Government's views on the latter issue were set out in paragraph 3.58 of the recent Economic Plan, Building on Reality, 1985-87. I would also refer the Deputies to my own comments in the course of the Dáil debate on the Plan on 17 October 1984, Official Report, Volume 352, column 2754 refers.
The Review Group on Forestry was established by me on 7 November 1984 with the following terms of reference.

With a view to ensuring that the country's afforestation programme and, in particular, the substantial resource which it represents, is developed and exploited to the best national advantage, having due regard to the role and functions of the National Development Corporation where relevant——
(1) to examine the present structure, organisation and operation of the Forest and Wildlife Service of the Department of Fisheries and Forestry;
(2) to consider what changes, if any, are necessary;
(3) to make specific recommendations on such changes; and
(4) to submit a report to the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry by 1 June 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Are we to take it from the Minister's reply that he is neglecting the proposal from the Irish Timber Council for the establishment of An tÚdarás Adhmaid? Are we to take it that he will not consider the establishment of a State-sponsored body in charge of forestry?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I think the Deputy is misinterpreting what I said.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: The Minister answered too many questions together.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I am sorry about that. Normally I am accused of not answering half the questions put to me. If I answered too many questions together I make no apology for it, and I mean that in the best sense. I do not want to be acrimonious about this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Deputy Molloy misinterpreted what I said. The document produced by the Irish Timber Council suggested the establishment of a timber board, an tÚdarás Adhmaid. I am looking at the whole structure and I have appointed a review group on which the Irish Timber Council are represented in order to establish an independent group and the best method to approach this problem, including, if necessary, the establishment of whatever authority they deem fit. Anything I say now in relation to my own view might be seen as preempting the deliberations of this review group, who have been given seven months to produce a report with recommendations.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: Are we to understand from the Minister's reply that, in spite of all the recommendations of the National Planning Board and the people involved in the timber industry, the Minister has no proposals for any change in the structure or organisation of the timber industry? He does not propose to establish a board, a semi-State body or a timber authority. How does he propose to market the increasing volume of timber which will be coming on the market when his Department are unable to give accurate estimates of what volume of timber will be coming through? There is one administrative staff member for every two in the field. This is a top heavy organisation which has no interest in marketing.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy does not seem to be asking a question.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: What proposals has the Minister? My first question asked if he had examined the recommendations of the National Planning Board. I take it he has examined but rejected those recommendations. Is that a fact?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: First, I do not accept the implications in the Deputy's statement that inaccurate information was given by the Department in relation to projections. Second, in relation to the National Planning Board's recommendations, I have scrutinised them in order to ensure that the industry get what they need, in other words, that they will be involved in deliberating on what is the best approach. I decided to establish a review group comprised of all interested parties operating within the industry. That includes the Irish Timber Council, private growers, processors and so on plus public servants who would have an input and make recommendations. I do not know what recommendations they will make in their report but all the interests within the industry have been included in the review group. That is the best way to go about it. I do not want to impose something that will not be acceptable to certain elements within the industry. It is much better to get the industry involved and to let them from their experience lay down the guidelines which should be followed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Does the Minister agree that it is said that the only Irish solution to every problem seems to be the establishment of a review body? What is required here is the political will to make a decision. The Minister is unable, afraid, does not have the ability or is postponing the decision for some other reason. There have been sufficient reports on the state of the Irish timber industry already. The IDA and the National Planning board have made their views known——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy cannot make a speech.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: The Minister has an abundance of information and facts upon which he could make a decision in regard to the future of the timber industry. Does the Minister agree that the State is losing £100 million yearly because of the cost of the inefficient operation of our forestry and timber industries? The information with regard to those industries has been sent to the Minister——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy is making speech after speech on supplementary questions and it is intolerable. I have said on numerous occasions that it is not possible to deal with policy at Question Time. It does not make sense.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I will endeavour to reply to Deputy Molloy's allegations — they were not questions. I am not in the business of providing Irish solutions to Irish problems; I will leave that to someone else. Is the Deputy suggesting that I should lay down the law regardless of what people in the industry think? Is he complaining because I am consulting with the people who matter in the industry, private growers, processors and so on? If he is let him say so——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: They have all made their views known.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: They have not. The throw away remark concerning £100 million being lost is the sort of statement that should not be made by someone with the Deputy's experience because it is not true.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: It is true.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: It is not true. The Deputy might as well have said £500 million.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: That figure relates to the softwood industry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McEllistrim Mr. McEllistrim
Speaker.P: Is there a change of plan in the Minister's Department regarding the sale of timber as the small purchaser seems to have been cut out recently?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy is introducing a totally different topic.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McEllistrim Mr. McEllistrim
Speaker.P: It is all related to the timber industry.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: This is about the setting-up of a State-sponsored body.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McEllistrim Mr. McEllistrim
Speaker.P: Has there been a change of plan in the Minister's Department in regard to not selling timber to the small purchaser?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: No.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McEllistrim Mr. McEllistrim
Speaker.P: There have been cases——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: If the Deputy gives me details concerning such cases I will look into them.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that people have doubts in regard to the value of this review group in view of the fact that the Minister set up his own internal review committee within his Department and that his technical experts have advised him that there is a need for a commercially orientated semi-State organisation to fully exploit our timber resources? He has expert advice available to him inside-and outside the industry——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Could the Deputy please ask a question?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: People are sceptical about a review body which seems to be comprised of those whose interests totally conflict——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: If the Deputy does not ask a question I will move on to the next one.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Could the Minister clarify the value of this review group when he has already——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is argument.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: As the Deputy said, I have the views of an internal group in my Department. Is the Deputy suggesting that I should not consult with other groups directly involved in the industry or that I should impose something on the industry?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: I would like some indication of the expertise of the members of the review body.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am calling Deputy Mac Giolla.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: This question was addressed to the Minister for the Public Service but it was transferred to the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry because the Minister would not wish to get rid of his own Department. While the review body are sitting for a number of years, what steps does the Minister intend to take to prevent the export of 12 per cent of our best quality timber to Northern Ireland and to increase the output of timber to ensure that our mills are not operating at 60 per cent capacity? In his reply the Minister referred to the National Development Corporation but I cannot recall exactly what he said. What role does he see for this mythical corporation in the development of our forests because I believe such an organisation does not exist?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Never mind about belief, ask a question.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: What did the Minister say about the National Development Corporation which, I understand, does not exist?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: With regard to the Deputy's remark about the review body sitting for years, I have already stated that I have given a deadline of 1 June 1985 to the review group to report. I have said this twice already. It is a question of months, not years. I refuse the allegation that the vast bulk of the best of our timber is going North.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: I know that 12 per cent is going North.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: It is more like 11 per cent. The input of the National Development Corporation to this area of activity will be decided when the review group have published their report and, if relevant, they will become involved in the further development of the industry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: Can the Minister say what timber and afforestation experience the members of the review body have? He also said earlier that he did not want to impose something on the timber industry which they did not want. In this regard is he now telling the House that the timber industry does not want this semi-State body although they recommended the setting up of such a body on numerous occasions? Is he aware of the tremendous opportunity for afforestation and expansion of the timber industry here to make a contribution to the economy?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I am fully aware of the potential of the industry and that is why I want to make sure that what we do now, when production is coming onstream in a substantial way, is the right way to do things. In order to ensure that, consultations should take place across the board. In relation to the experience of the people involved in the review body, many of them have 30 or 40 years' experience of dealing with different aspects of the industry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Could the Minister tell us the names of the members of this review body?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That seems to be a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Is the Minister prepared to tell the House who the members are?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: It is public knowledge.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Would the Minister give an assurance that the people he has appointed to this review body are not just Fine Gael activists, because that is what they seem to be from the names which we have heard?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I was wondering when Deputy Molloy would come around to that in his usual way. They are not Fine Gael activists: they are people who have vast experience in the industry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Mr. Hussey and Mr. O'Keeffe.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Mr. Hussey has forgotten more about forestry than the Deputy will ever know about it and I am privileged to have the services of Mr. O'Keeffe as chairman.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am calling Question No. 11.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: The Minister is blushing.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: It would take more than the Deputy to make the Minister blush.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Acid Rain Threat.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he will make a statement on the ever-growing threat to our forests by acid rain; and if he will initiate a further study because of growing evidence of damage to our forests.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Flaherty Miss Flaherty
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry whether there is any evidence of the amount of damage being done to Irish forests by acid rain; and if there are any proposals to deal with this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 11 and 12 together.

There is no evidence to suggest that Irish forests have been damaged as a result of acid rain. I am satisfied that measures already initiated for monitoring of rainfall will enable the situation to be kept under constant review.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware of the ever-increasing level of sulphur dioxide in the atmosphere and the concern that has been expressed recently by a number of botanists about damage to our forests? Will he inform the House of his attitude to the most recent EC directive on air pollution from industrial sources? Further, will he state if inter-departmental discussions have taken place on this matter?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I am aware of the damage caused by atmospheric pollution to major tracts of forests elsewhere, particularly in Germany. However, I would point out that experts even in that country disagree on some of the factors that they attribute to this problem. Some experts say it is due to bad husbandry but I am not prepared to disregard the dangers as lightly as that. The monitoring of facets of acid rain in Ireland has been undertaken by An Foras Forbartha. Atmospheric pollution is a matter primarily for the Minister for the Environment but, as the House will know, I have a deep interest in this for obvious reasons because of the dangers to our fisheries and our forests. Five sites are being monitored on a daily basis in respect of wet and dry conditions. The sites are at Glencree, County Wicklow, Dublin Airport, Kinsealy, Trinity College and monitoring on a site at Howth will commence shortly. The research branch of my Department — the FWS — are co-operating with the Macauley Institute in Aberdeen and a project is underway to compare the situation in that part of Scotland with the west of Ireland. The FWS are also co-operating with the ESB in setting up a monitoring post in the Slieve Bloom mountain areas. The contacts are ongoing and the situation is being watched with some concern because of the danger involved.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: The Minister has responsibility for our forests and this problem will have major implications if it remains unchecked. Will the Minister give his opinion regarding what I would call the disjointed effort at present undertaken by all Government Departments, agencies and local authorities? Would he favour a central environmental protection agency to deal with all aspects of pollution? It is obvious from his answer there is a whole range——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That seems very far removed from the questions on the Order Paper.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: The Minister will be aware that a major problem will arise when the ESB generating station at Moneypoint goes into operation in 1985. The Minister will also be aware that substantial grants and loans are available to install in the chimneys at Moneypoint the necessary sophisticated equipment to ensure that pollution will be kept to the minimum.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I appeal to the Deputy in all seriousness not to make long speeches every time he gets up.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: It is a very important problem and a major one.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That may be and perhaps the Deputy should request a special debate if the problem is that serious. That disqualifies it all the more for dealing with it at Question Time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: I was putting a supplementary question to the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy was making a supplementary speech.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: I was asking the Minister if he was aware of the imminent threat that will arise as a result of the Moneypoint station. Now is the time to act because the chimneys will be completed soon and the factory will be brought into production some time in 1985. Grants and loans are available from the Community but they have not been availed of and I ask the Minister to use his influence to see this is done.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: The Deputy is asking me to give my view on certain questions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: I am asking the Minister to use his influence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I am as aware as he is of the dangers. The fact is it is not within the aegis of my Department to decide what goes in to the chimneys at Moneypoint.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: What comes out of the chimneys is the Minister's responsibility.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Yes, and I am concerned about that. The Deputy can be assured that this matter will receive the attention it deserves at the appropriate level.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: I was not clear from the Minister's first reply if inter-departmental discussions are taking place in relation to problems that may arise from plants such as Moneypoint.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: There are statutory regulations governing all inter-departmental discussions in relation to these matters. As I said before, the Deputy can be assured that the attention these matters are getting is commensurate with their importance.

MainHeading.RHead: - New Species of Plants and Trees
MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - New Species of Plants and Trees.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if his Department have an ongoing research and development programme for the propagation of new species of plants and trees.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Such work is carried out as part of the ongoing research programme undertaken by the Forest and Wildlife Service. For a description of various activities in the sphere of tree genetics I would refer the Deputy to the annual reports of the Forest and Wildlife Service which are available in the Library.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he will make available in the whole country the same level of grant-aid for forestry development as is available in the 12 western counties.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: The grant levels payable in western counties reflect the special provisions of the EC western package scheme. While an extension of these grant levels to the rest of the country is not practicable, the separate planting grants scheme applicable to counties outside the western package area is being examined to see whether some improvements would be feasible.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Native Sawn Timber Outlets.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if a record is kept of the number of timber retail outlets which stock native sawn timber and the demand for this timber.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: My Department do not compile records of such retail outlets. However, I can tell the Deputy that the level of demand for native timber nowadays would be about 40 per cent of the market.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that many retail outlets carry a very meagre stock of softwood timber? Will the Minister not agree there is need for greater promotion of native timber? We are making very little headway so far as import substitution is concerned in connection with this matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I do not accept that little progress has been made. Since 1980 the share of the market held by Irish sawmills has doubled. This indicates that inroads are being made into the Irish market and that Irish timber is now being established as a commodity as good as if not better, in many cases, than the imported product. The problem here is that we have not enough to meet our demands. There is, after all, a 40 per cent shortfall in our capacity to supply timber to the industry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: Would the Minister not agree that, if there is not enough to go around, it is very strange that the majority of the produce in the constituency which I represent goes across the Border for sawing, coming back in as timber products or as sawn plank timber?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: The Deputy will realise that in so far as exports to the North are concerned I can do little about that. We apply a tender system and because the North is a member of the EC, the same as we are, I cannot apply any restrictions in relation to exports of timber from there.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Does the Minister not know that the tender system is primitive? I have already raised that matter in the House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: It is a tender and quota system, Deputy. This is the subject of a report and recommendations to be published within the next few days.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: That is what the Minister said the last time.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The remaining questions will appear on tomorrow's Order Paper.

Speaker.hpid: The Tánaiste Dick Spring
Speaker.P: It is proposed to take Business in the following order: Nos. 6, 7, 8 and 12. Private Members' Business, No. 69, will be taken from 7 p.m. until 8.30 p.m.

By agreement and notwithstanding anything in Standing Orders the proceedings on items 6, 7 and 8 shall be brought to a conclusion not later than 5.30 p.m., 6.30 p.m. and 9 p.m. respectively and the Ministers for Justice, Industry, Trade, Commerce and Tourism and Fisheries and Forestry shall be called on not later than 5.20 p.m., 6.25 p.m. and 8.55 p.m. respectively to conclude the debates. Speaker.P: Are the arrangements for today's business agreed?
Agreed.

Speaker.P: May I ask the Tánaiste if he is in a position to give the House the date of the 1985 budget?

Speaker.P: No, I am not in a position to give the Deputy that date, but we shall have it within a matter of days — in a week.

Speaker.P: Will it be in January?

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: It will be announced in due course.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: May I raise a matter with the Tánaiste? I would refer him to the fact that there have been developments with regard to two important constitutional offices, namely those of the Chief Justice and of the Attorney General. Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That does not arise on the Order of Business. I am ruling that it does not arise on the Order of Business.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy Haughey, I am ruling that that does not arise on the Order of Business.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick

Speaker.P: The Deputy is not in order in making a speech about it.

Speaker.P: I assume that these matters will be brought to the attention of the House in due course.

Speaker.P: I want to ask another question, with all due deference.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am sure Deputy Haughey knows ——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
